items.title: [UI] Sign In button not visible properly
items.body:
**Describe the bug**

The sign in button is not visible properly.
And there is a lot of space on the left side of the nav bar.
Also the arrow on the left, is slightly hidden.

**To Reproduce**

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. Go to: https://community-tc.services.mozilla.com/tasks/UgHmihQXScq9V29fgpf2ZA/runs/0/logs/https%3A%2F%2Fcommunity-tc.services.mozilla.com%2Fapi%2Fqueue%2Fv1%2Ftask%2FUgHmihQXScq9V29fgpf2ZA%2Fruns%2F0%2Fartifacts%2Fpublic%2Flogs%2Flive.log
2. Open it on a mobile browser (not toggling the mobile view on chrome).

**Expected behavior**

There can be 2 approaches to this:
1. Remove the sign in button, and it will be present in the navigation bar activity.
2. Move the nav bar button (three rectangles) and search bar to the left, so that there will be space for the sign in button

**Screenshots**

![Screenshot_20200816-083841 (1)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/37565807/90530262-49ed8880-e192-11ea-9616-ea57d9b76449.png)

**Platform (please complete the following information):**

 - OS: Android 9
 - Browser: Chrome
 - Version of chrome: 84.0.4147.125
- Device: Xiaomi Mi A1

items.title: [simulator] Write a "manual" provisioner
items.body:
This will be a provisioner that does not use any metrics to provision, simply relying on user configuration to decide how much capacity to have at any given time.

A first cut could be one where there is a constant `N` workers at all times.

A next cut could be one where for any given hour of the day, the user sets a constant `N` of workers.

Maybe there's even more we can go from there.

items.title: worker-runner 32.0.0 seems not to reregister static worker
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
Our [mac worker](https://community-tc.services.mozilla.com/provisioners/proj-taskcluster/worker-types/gw-ci-macos/workers/proj-taskcluster/63-135-170-250) has gone offline with the failure message in the logs:

```
2020/08/05 13:52:25 Loading worker-runner configuration from /etc/generic-worker/runner.yml
2020/08/05 13:52:25 Configuring with provider static
2020/08/05 13:52:26 Could not register worker: 
CALL SUMMARY
============
Method: POST
Service: community-tc.services.mozilla.com:
Response Body:
{
  "code": "InputError",
  "message": "Worker proj-taskcluster/63-135-170-250 has expired\n\n---\n\n* method:     registerWorker\n* errorCode:  InputError\n* statusCode: 400\n* time:       2020-08-05T17:52:26.687Z",
  "requestInfo": {
    "method": "registerWorker",
    "params": {},
    "payload": "(OMITTED)",
    "time": "2020-08-05T17:52:26.687Z"
  }
}
Attempts: 1
(Permanent) HTTP response code 400
HTTP/2.0 400 Bad Request
Content-Length: 358
Access-Control-Allow-Headers: X-Requested-With,Content-Type,Authorization,Accept,Origin,Cache-Control
Access-Control-Allow-Methods: OPTIONS,GET,HEAD,POST,PUT,DELETE,TRACE,CONNECT
Access-Control-Allow-Origin: *
Access-Control-Max-Age: 900
Access-Control-Request-Method: *
Alt-Svc: clear
Cache-Control: no-store no-cache must-revalidate
Content-Security-Policy: report-uri /__cspreport__;default-src 'none';frame-ancestors 'none';
Content-Type: application/json; charset=utf-8
Date: Wed, 05 Aug 2020 17:52:26 GMT
Etag: W/"166-CaBdMIN7K84lJDEWcndixASfNto"
Server: openresty
Strict-Transport-Security: max-age=31536000
Via: 1.1 google
X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff
X-For-Request-Id: 128171eb-d87a-4040-8567-e5c2948285dd
X-For-Trace-Id: a15737a52764d11a83fbe979b2d3be3a

{
  "code": "InputError",
  "message": "Worker proj-taskcluster/63-135-170-250 has expired\n\n---\n\n* method:     registerWorker\n* errorCode:  InputError\n* statusCode: 400\n* time:       2020-08-05T17:52:26.687Z",
  "requestInfo": {
    "method": "registerWorker",
    "params": {},
    "payload": "(OMITTED)",
    "time": "2020-08-05T17:52:26.687Z"
  }
}
``` 

This suggests that the worker reregistration and updating of generic-worker taskcluster credentials that worker-runner performs has not worked.

Reregistration in worker-runner was released in v31.0.0 in #3073 which landed in release 31.0.0. Worker runner 32.0.0 and generic-worker 32.0.0 are deployed on worker `proj-taskcluster/63-135-170-250`, so automatic worker reregistration should work.

**Taskcluster version**
32.0.0

items.title: Be more forgiving of the pull_request action types

milestone.title: GitHub Service Refresh
milestone.description:
Vague ideas for epics:
 * Finish off the Checks API support and announce a plan to drop status support
    * complete support for custom output from checks
    * rerun support (via actions)
 * Drop support for v0 .taskcluster.ymls
 * Store all webhooks and send them to a pulse exchange for consumption (for example by hooks)
 * UI improvements:
    * Finding webhooks, tasks by repo / sha
    * Improved .taskcluster.yml editor that can validate and do test-runs against a webhook 
 * Other GH ideas we'd need to agree on (RFC) beforehand:
   * A way to remove the huge boilerplate .taskcluster.yml's in every repo
   * A way to call GitHub APIs from a task, with suitable scope-style control (allowing posting comments, pushing lint runs, etc.)
   * ..your ideas here

items.body:
We are seeing some of this error:

```
Message validation failed. 
Schema Validation Failed!
Rejecting Schema: https://community-tc.services.mozilla.com/schemas/github/v1/github-pull-request-message.json#
Errors:
  * data.action should be equal to one of the allowed values
```

the content of that message is passed unchanged from GitHub, so likely the error is due to a new action defined by GitHub that our schema isn't aware of.  Let's start by verifying that.

Rather than just add this new action to the schema, let's make the schema accept any action.  Then next time GitHub adds an action, we won't see failures like this.

items.title: Replace use of hasPrefixedScopes in docker-worker with scope expressions
items.body:
@tomprince did something similar in #3327, but left `buildVolumeBindings` un-changed.  That's the last use of `hasPrefixedScopes`, so fixing it will allow us to remove this function's definition.

Why?
 * taskcluster-lib-scopes allows generation of better error messages for the user
 * `hasPrefixedScopes` is only used in docker-worker, so not well-tested and well-used, and poorly-tested security-sensitive code is bad
 * removing code generally simplifies a codebase -- less code to read, less code to have bugs

Note that running docker-worker's tests locally can be difficult.  It's OK to make what you think the change should look like and create a draft PR, then watch the test results on that PR.

items.title: visualize tasks and workers together in simulator

milestone.title: Provisioning is Efficient
milestone.description: Use whatever tools we have in our toolbox to make our provisioning spend the least money while also having good latency and throughput.

items.body:
The idea here is to try to make one visualization that packs a lot of information as to what's happening in a provisioning simulation.  This is not to the exclusion of graphing metrics or calculating values that matter, but intended to let us "understand" how a particular provisioning approach works in a situation, or how two approaches differ.

Weird sketch here:

![image.png](https://images.zenhubusercontent.com/5ee7e1341cf3ef736f282afd/3ea821d5-5f30-4398-956e-0febaa1532bf)

The idea is to show the throughput of tasks on the left side, and the worker capacity on the right side.

* highlights the things we want to avoid -- idleness and pending -- but in a way that we can see what portion of the overall load those represent
* shows the rate of task execution by the angle of the lines of shading on the left
* shows the rate of worker churn by the angle of the lines of shading on the right
* shows total concurrent tasks by the width of the left side
* shows total amount of worker capacity by the width of the right side
* shows it all in a way that we can compare across time and see things like the worker surge that follows a big spike in tasks


I think the left side would be the concatenation of all tasks, from youngest to oldest, with each task's width given by the remaining duration, and the color by its status (yellow=pending, orange=running) and identity (subtle shade differences based on taskId)

the right side would be the concatenation of all workers, with the width given by the worker's total work per second, colored fractionally purple for running and blue for idle (or starting up), with subtle shade differences for worker name

I suppose different colors for starting up and idle would be good

items.title: Support deprecating db methods and removing after a major revision
items.body:
We recently introduced a little twist to the compatibility matrix: service upgrades must jump by at most one major version at a time.  So going from v50.1.2 to v52.0.5 is not guaranteed not to break.

That means that if a method is deprecated in v50.1.2, then the method needs to remain functional throughout the v51.x.y series, as a deployment might upgrade from v50.1.2 to v51.x.y an expect things to work.  But that function can be removed completely in v52.

So basically, such functions need to wait for two major versions before they can be removed.  Let's find a way to ensure that, either with a test or in a way that's obvious in reviews.  That might be as simple as changing

```yaml
deprecated: true
```
to
```yaml
deprecated: until v52
```
where v52 is two major versions ahead of the current version when this change lands.

items.title: docker-worker pulls old version of livelog, taskcluster-proxy
items.body:
monopacker saves the most recent version of livelog on the AMI, but docker-worker just uses hard-coded versions:

https://github.com/taskcluster/taskcluster/blob/a53f88c1a5872eec3180f35abb969dbc02dca248/workers/docker-worker/config.yml#L64-L65

We should find a way to use the appropriate version -- either passing that through from monopacker, or always using the same version as docker-worker's version.

This is probably causing slow startup, as those images need to be pulled.  They are tiny, but still..

items.title: Incorrect spelling of response as reposnse
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
Executing the Taskcluster client for shell with the arguments `api github` prints the description of the GitHub service, but response is spelled incorrectly as reposnse.

**To Reproduce**

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. Download the [client shell binary](https://github.com/taskcluster/taskcluster/tree/master/clients/client-shell).
2. Give execute permissions with chmod
3. Execute with arguments. Ex: `./taskcluster-darwin-amd64 api github`
4. The output contains the typo

**Expected behavior**
Output with the correct spelling of response

**Platform (please complete the following information):**

 - OS: Linux and MacOS

items.title: Generate a map of TC versions to DB versions
items.body:
For https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1655155 I spent some time making

| Taskcluster Version | DB Version | Notes                                                   |
|---------------------|------------|---------------------------------------------------------|
| v32.0.0             | 0017       | notify step 1+2                                         |
| v33.0.0             | 0018       | index step 1                                            |
|                     | 0019       | queue artifacts step 1 <-- **firefox-ci-tc is here** |
|                     | 0020       | queue tasks step 1 (failed in TCW)                      |
|                     | 0021       | queue task groups step 1 (fast)                         |
| v34.0.0             | 0022       | queue task dependencies step 1 (~16 minutes) <-- **community-tc is here**            |
|                     | 0023       | github builds step 1+2 (fast)                           |
|                     | 0024       | queue artifacts step 2 (fast)                           |
|                     | 0025       | auth roles step 1+2 (fast)                              |
|                     | 0026       | index step 2 (fast)                                     |
|                     | 0027       | web-server github access tokens (fast)                  |
|                     | 0028       | queue tasks, task groups, dependencies step 2 (fast)    |
|                     | 0029       | worker-manager worker pools step 1+2 (fast)             |
|                     | 0030       | hash bugfix (fast)                                      |
| v35.0.0             | 0031       | worker pool errors bugfix (fast)                        |
|                     | 0032       | hooks last-fire step 1+2                                |
|                     | 0033       | hooks queues step 1+2                                   |
|                     | 0034       | crypto functions (fast)                                 |
|                     | 0035       | hooks hooks step 1+2 (fast)                             |
|                     | 0036       | github integrations step 1+2 (fast)                     |
|                     | 0037       | github checks step 1+2                                  |
|                     | 0038       | web-server sessions step 1+2                            |
|                     | 0039       | web-server authorization codes step 1+2                 |
| master              | 0040       | web-server access tokens step 1+2                       |

It'd be really cool if that was done automatically in `yarn generate` and `yarn release` and included in the deployment docs.  Bonus points for also including the last release's worth in the release notes.

The third column can come from a "description" property in the migration script.

items.title: taskcluster and websocktunnel have inconsistent image tag names for the same version
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
Take version 34.0.1 for example, the tag for image taskcluster/taskcluster is `v34.0.1`, whereas it is `34.0.1` for image taskcluster/websocktunnel.

I'm not sure if there is a historical reason for the inconsistency. If not then maybe it's a good idea to make them consistent, i.e., either both have the `v` in the tag name, or neither has it.

**To Reproduce**

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. Try `sudo docker pull taskcluster/taskcluster:v34.0.1` and `sudo docker pull taskcluster/websocktunnel:34.0.1` and see both succeed.
2. Try `sudo docker pull taskcluster/taskcluster:34.0.1` or `sudo docker pull taskcluster/websocktunnel:v34.0.1` and see either succeeds.

**Expected behavior**

Consistent naming for docker image tags.

**Taskcluster version**

Found in version 34.0.1. Probably all lower versions too.

**Screenshots**

n/a

**Platform (please complete the following information):**

n/a

**Additional context**

n/a

items.title: listWorkerPoolErrors should only return errors for that workerPool
items.body:
https://github.com/taskcluster/taskcluster/blob/994a671a840bad712a2d63ab888698b20b7d8c6a/services/worker-manager/src/api.js#L326-L347

there is no `errorId` param to this function.  And getWorkerPoolErrors only takes two parameters:

https://github.com/taskcluster/taskcluster/blob/994a671a840bad712a2d63ab888698b20b7d8c6a/services/worker-manager/src/data.js#L188-L193

And `db.fns.get_worker_pool_errors` always returns the whole table, rather than a particular pool's errors:

https://github.com/taskcluster/taskcluster/blob/994a671a840bad712a2d63ab888698b20b7d8c6a/db/versions/0031.yml#L227

let's get that fixed up before the next release!

items.title: Worker Pool Errors should be sorted by date
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
Currently worker pool errors are sorted in the UI by date, but this only applies on a per-page basis. We're really returning chunks of errors by errorId (I think) and then sorting the chunk by date. I'm not sure if this is fixed in the v2 migration we just landed. If not, let's fix it there now.

**To Reproduce**

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. Go to https://firefox-ci-tc.services.mozilla.com/worker-manager/gecko-t%2Ft-win10-64-gpu-s/errors
2. Click on the next page button
3. See that the most recent error is always from more recently than the bottom of the previous page

**Expected behavior**
We should sort these by recency since that's the only useful way to view them.

**Taskcluster version**
33.0.0-1-g4c4ad4262

**Screenshots**
<!-- If applicable, add screenshots to help explain your problem. -->

**Platform (please complete the following information):**

 - OS: [e.g. windows]
 - Browser if applicable [e.g. firefox, safari]
 - Version if applicable [e.g. 57]

**Additional context**
This made debugging https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1645994 difficult

items.title: Rewrite 0020 migration to be able to happen online
items.body:
Migation 0020 took too long in the TCW this weekend.  We need to find a way to do this without downtime.

Rough outline from the team meeting just now: 
 * operate in a mode where we have both an "old" (queue_tasks_entities/queue_task_group_active_sets_entities) and "new" (tasks) table
 * provide some mechanism to migrate tasks one-by-one (or in small batches) from old to new

Parameters on the solution:
 * Online
 * Result must match the existing version 0020 exactly when finished (since we've already deployed 0020 elsewhere)
 * Optional: 
   * Support downgrades
     * Also online
       * If the upgrade only partially completed

items.title: smoketests sometimes fail with role-related issue
items.body:
```
AssertionError [ERR_ASSERTION]: Expected values to be loosely deep-equal: (while executing task Create role and expand smoketest (--target roles))

[
  'assume:project:taskcluster:smoketest:cTTAcdksS6qEBLcszMA_4w:abc'
]

should loosely deep-equal

[
  'assume:project:taskcluster:smoketest:cTTAcdksS6qEBLcszMA_4w:abc',
  'project:taskcluster:smoketest:abc/*'
]
    at Object.run (/home/dustin/p/taskcluster/infrastructure/tooling/src/smoketest/checks/role.js:43:12)
    at processTicksAndRejections (internal/process/task_queues.js:97:5)
    at async TaskGraph._runNode (/home/dustin/p/taskcluster/node_modules/console-taskgraph/src/taskgraph.js:184:18) {
  generatedMessage: true,
  code: 'ERR_ASSERTION',
  actual: [Array],
  expected: [Array],
  operator: 'deepEqual'
}
error Command failed with exit code 1.
info Visit https://yarnpkg.com/en/docs/cli/run for documentation about this command.
```

This happened at v32.0.0 and v33.0.0, and it's intermittent.  That check adds the role `project:taskcluster:smoketest:cTTAcdksS6qEBLcszMA_4w:abc` and then immediately expands it, so perhaps this is an issue of a delay in updating the resolvers.

items.title: digest function not found
items.body:
Shortly after upgrading to version 0018, which is the first to use the `sha512` function, we see lots of

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/28673/87861585-ab150880-c915-11ea-8590-dc97c004d3dd.png)

in the logs (sorry for the image, yay stackdriver).

The `digest(text, text)` function is in pgcrypto, and the `sha512` function is defined in version 0015 and is right out of the [docs](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/11/pgcrypto.html#id-1.11.7.34.5).  The index service is correctly finding index entries, so this function has to be working somehow.

.. add yours here!

items.title: GitHub Checks custom text output uses wrong filename
make a general utility for returning a row or undefined
items.body:
All of the `get_xyz` DB functions return either a single row or, on not found, an empty set.  We have a bunch of `fromDbRows` functions scattered about that basically just check the length and either return the row or return undefined.  Let's write that in one place.

Note that the `fromDbRows` functions also change the capitalization.  I think in most cases, where those functions are only called in a few places and their results consumed locally, that's not necessary.

items.title: make a general utility for paginating through a table
Update signing support to verify that all columns are considered in the signature
[client-shell] MacOSX taskcluster cli tool isn't signed/notarized
items.body:
**Describe the bug**

When downloading from the [client-shell readme](https://github.com/taskcluster/taskcluster/releases/download/v32.0.0/taskcluster-darwin-amd64), running the binary on recent MacOSX versions gets a warning about being unable to verify the developer, and requires the extra steps mentioned in [Apple's support](https://support.apple.com/en-gb/guide/mac-help/mh40616/mac) in order to run.

**To Reproduce**

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

Download and run the cli tool, without having done so before on that installation

**Expected behavior**

The binary should be trusted.

**Platform (please complete the following information):**

MacOSX 10.15.*

So the question for me is: What's the balance between this trust set-up and getting the binary trusted? I suspect this is a signing/notarisation step, and it may well be that it's more effort than we need given the scale of the current audience.

items.title: generic-worker workerTypeMetadata in worker pool definitions not in task log headers
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
By specifying `workerTypeMetadata` generic-worker config setting in worker pool definitions, it should be possible to add information to all task log headers that run on a worker pool.

We have `workerTypeMetadata` specified in the worker pool definitions, like [this one](https://community-tc.services.mozilla.com/worker-manager/proj-taskcluster%2Fgw-ci-windows2012r2-amd64) however, it isn't making its way into task log headers, such as [here](https://community-tc.services.mozilla.com/tasks/TlFuJUi5Rfi48RuyY6sD_Q/runs/0/logs/live/https%3A%2F%2Fcommunity-tc.services.mozilla.com%2Fapi%2Fqueue%2Fv1%2Ftask%2FTlFuJUi5Rfi48RuyY6sD_Q%2Fruns%2F0%2Fartifacts%2Fpublic%2Flogs%2Flive.log#L2-23).

Either this is getting swallowed by worker-runner, or it could be a generic-worker bug. I think the latter is reasonably unlikely as this code hasn't really changed since it was created, so the probably cause at this point is that worker-runner is swallowing it.

I did notice that there is special treatment of `workerTypeMetadata` in the worker runner code. I couldn't see any tests for it though.

**Taskcluster version**
32.0.0 for both services and workers.

items.title: Support scalingRatio for workerpools

labels.name: Estimate: Medium
labels.description: A medium amount of time is probably needed to resolve this

milestone.title: Provisioning is Efficient
milestone.description: Use whatever tools we have in our toolbox to make our provisioning spend the least money while also having good latency and throughput.

items.body:
This bug originally read:
> All worker types will inevitably spin up more workers than are needed, I refer to that as overprovisioning.  gecko-t/t-win7-32 is overprovisioned about 4x more than other windows test workers.  I would like to adjust our metrics/heuristics which determine when we create new workers and how many we create.  I am fine with slightly longer queues.

I'm going to take this as a starting point for a bug to support scalingRatio again as a simple tool to help admins dial in their efficiency-to-cost ratios.

Scaling ratio is a number in the range `(0, 1]` where `1.0` would mean "spawn 1 worker per pending task" and `0.5` would mean "spawn 1 worker for ever 2 pending tasks".

I'm not sure this is exactly the formulation we'll use (or if we'll use scaling ratio for sure) by the time we get to the sprint but I'm writing it this way for now.

items.title: Add .nvmrc
items.body:
`nvm` will look at a `.nvmrc` file to decide what version of Node to use.  This would make it a bit easier to install/use the version of node for a particular checkout:
```
lamport ~/p/taskcluster [renovate/node-12.x*] $ echo 12.18.2 > .nvmrc 
lamport ~/p/taskcluster [renovate/node-12.x*] $ cat .nvmrc 
12.18.2
lamport ~/p/taskcluster [renovate/node-12.x*] $ nvm use
Found '/home/dustin/p/taskcluster/.nvmrc' with version <12.18.2>
Now using node v12.18.2 (npm v6.14.5)
```

Can I add that file and add a generate task to update it?

items.title: Decision task ignores TASKCLUSTER_HEAD_REV
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
Sometimes links to taskcluster CI tasks from github PR UI are for the wrong commit.

**To Reproduce**

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. Go to https://github.com/taskcluster/taskcluster/pull/3103
2. Click on the green tick next to commit bb91dd2
3. Click on "Details" next to task "Build/test generic-worker (multiuser engine) on Windows Server 2012 R2 (amd64)" (note this is the third taskcluster task listed when I view it, ymmv)
4. You should be taken to https://github.com/taskcluster/taskcluster/runs/830725558
5. Note that this page of the UI correctly refers to commit bb91dd2 at the top of the page. So far so good.
6. Note that the correct task is selected with a blue background in the left column on the page ("Build/test generic-worker (mult...")
7. Click on "View task in Taskcluster"
8. You should be taken to [task F8vva6ToTuCAourtdTiktw](https://community-tc.services.mozilla.com/tasks/F8vva6ToTuCAourtdTiktw).  
9. Note the task has the correct title "Build/test generic-worker (multiuser engine) on Windows Server 2012 R2 (amd64)".
10. Click on "Payload"
11. Note that the payload contains `"GITHUB_SHA": "41acdacab93f73704f86069727664b61b0144072"`. This is a different commit! Looking at it, we see it is a _later_ commit, since the commit we expected to see (bb91dd2) is actually its parent:

```
$ git log -n1 --pretty=raw 41acdacab93f73704f86069727664b61b0144072
commit 41acdacab93f73704f86069727664b61b0144072
tree 35fcd0773b4b6ec830d94f27a359698f17cc849c
parent bb91dd2920ed3e94ea2256c2911f68baf306cb74
author Pete Moore <pmoore@mozilla.com> 1593626808 +0200
committer Pete Moore <pmoore@mozilla.com> 1593695077 +0200
gpgsig -----BEGIN PGP SIGNATURE-----
 Comment: GPGTools - http://gpgtools.org
 
 iQFHBAABCAAxFiEEhe6Nva+1y60nOjNRgpX+d7R1/rwFAl7922UTHHBtb29yZUBt
 b3ppbGxhLmNvbQAKCRCClf53tHX+vERFB/9SeEGHJpBdmCTiYkLbxFOYth8c8JAw
 uskZ9r5WPBHmVKbX0BvJTbaya8BBidbQ5i3j/QN+JlZCWAFI7i7PL2uGrHWvdDr+
 bUkDxEZ8MjblE7LpbTn/2iMdrG7SggJ00JbS2dy8whtQuBm4gO2deuGtYLdjTaT2
 Pk+2jjzzcXR5DXkc5tWKgvz9N6zQjP15Xpqqlst0b61z4DoXD3rrT11qnjc25KDj
 B+eb69ljVSiyL3fQz76zhveuZiq/cneGwtK6B1dR7s/CAx1y5kcMs0cpAVe4PzK7
 AUN8rYhL7hF+xUtRPIOw2ZedmEu/ZcbRVDYkcn6517mR0fO9FJjCbNR5
 =8q+w
 -----END PGP SIGNATURE-----

    Issue 2934: Part 3 - Skip mock db tests (issue #3131)
```

**Expected behavior**
The link tasks linked against a given commit in a github PR should be the task created for that commit for that PR.

**Taskcluster version**
31.0.0

items.title: Figure out if there are any other migrations on July 11 (TCW)
items.body: During the postgres 1.0 migration, there were a couple of migrations we weren't aware of which blocked us from being able to test certain functionalities during the TCW until the other migrations were done. Let's try to figure out if there's anything happening on July 11 so that we are better prepared.

items.title: Run the performance test suite on the large tables db migrations
items.body: ...and check that performance is not affected.

items.title: Figure out how much time the DB upgrade will take on July 11
items.body:
Blocker: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1648609 

Notes by DB version:
 * 0013 (add worker capacity) - fast
 * 0014 (add worker.secrets) - fast
 * 0015 (add sha512) - fast
 * 0016 (add uuid_to_slugid, slugid_to_uuid) - fast
 * 0017 (denylisted_addresses) - fast
 * 0018 (queue_artifacts)
   * create table - 42m
   * create primary key - 24m
   * set not null - 4m (?!)
 * 0019 (tasks)
   * create table - 4h 20m
   * add primary key - 7m
   * add task_group index - 4m
   * add task_group index for unresolved - 3m
   * set not null - 3m
 * 0020 (task groups) - fast
 * 0021 (task dependencies)
   * create table - 8m
   * not null - fast
   * primary key - 4m
   * task_dependencies_dependent_task_id_idx - fast
 * 0022 (indexes)
   * indexed_tasks
     * create table - 1m
     * add primary key - 2m
   * index_namespaces
     * create table - 8s
     * add primary key - 30s
     * sha512_index_namespaces_idx - 15s
     * sha512_indexed_tasks_idx - 1m

Grand total, then, is about 6h.

As a bonus, we use a lot less space:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/28673/86922892-48449580-c0fb-11ea-83b0-f1c0affecfa4.png)

Downgrade times:
 * 0022 -> 0021 - 20m
 * 0021 -> 0020 - 50m
 * 0020 -> 0019 - fast
 * 0019 -> 0018 - 3h 10m
 * 0018 -> 0017
   * insert into - 10h
   * add primary key - 34m

items.title: Remove fake db functions
items.body:
Now that we've moved away from Azure and are using Postgres, the time it takes to run tests via a local postgres db vs fake db functions is not much of a big difference. Rather than having us duplicate the db business logic in two places, let's just run our tests with the postgres db. This will consist of the following changes:
* Delete `db/src/fakes`
* Remove the automation that runs the tests twice
* Update the guideline docs to reflect the new changes to step 2 of the migration

items.title: Ensure postgres is using a fixed collation

labels.name: Estimate: Small
labels.description: A small amount of time is probably needed to resolve this

items.body:
This seems to be different in CI and locally.

It can be checked with
```
SELECT datcollate AS collation
FROM pg_database 
WHERE datname = current_database();
```

so let's check it.

items.title: port the queue's artifacts table to use normal DB tables

labels.name: TCW
labels.description: Should be migrated in a TCW

* queue_artifacts_entities

This table has 217 million rows!

Broken out from #2932, as this can be done largely separately from that issue.

items.title: [worker-runner] handle shutdowns in once place, log about it
items.body: Shutdowns are currently handled similarly in every provider.  Let's move that out to a single place (looking forward to #2886) and also log when shutting down -- currently workers just stop logging when terminated!

items.title: Build all binaries in `yarn build`
items.body:
Right now, yarn build builds services docker images, but not workers or other tools.

We have console-taskgraph tasks to make those builds already, so let's do that, and put it all in some convenient location.

items.title: Port the namespaces_entities table to use a normal DB table
items.body: From https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1626314#c26, `namespaces_entities` has about 1592344 rows.

items.title: Port the queue_task_requirement_entities table to use a normal DB table
items.body:
From https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1626314#c26:

* queue_task_requirement_entities: 837635 rows

We were able to migrate the workers table in 1 second (~40,000 workers). Assuming we can migrate things at a rate of 40k/second, then migrating queue_task_requirement_entities should take ~21 seconds. That should probably be fine and we don't need to do this in a TCW.

items.title: Port the queue_task_groups_entities table to use a normal DB table
items.body:
From https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1626314#c26:

*  queue_task_groups_entities: 469297 rows

We were able to migrate the workers table in 1 second (~40,000 workers). Assuming we can migrate things at a rate of 40k/second, then migrating `queue_task_groups_entities` should take ~12 seconds. That should probably be fine and we don't need to do this in a TCW.

items.title: Port the queue_task_group_active_sets_entities table to use a normal DB table
items.body:
This is a relatively small table. From https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1626314#c26:
* queue_task_group_active_sets_entities: 24818 rows

items.title: Port the clients_entities table to use a normal DB table
items.body: Clients are signed and encrypted.

items.title: Add support for data signing
items.body:
Some of our tables that are still using taskcluster-lib-entities use signing to protect the integrity of the data. In order to successfully move away from taskcluster-lib-entities and migrate those tables to postgres phase 2, we would need to add inherent support for signing.

Tables affected:
* clients_entities - auth
* hooks_entities - hooks
* last_fire_3_entities - hooks
* queues_entities - hooks
* secrets_entities - secrets
* access_token_table_entities - web_server
* authorization_codes_table_entities - web_server
* github_access_token_table_entities - web_server
* session_storage_table_entities - web_server

https://github.com/pypa/virtualenv/issues/1857

This is causing all of our Python CI tasks to fail.

items.title: tests to no longer write to /workers/generic-worker directory

labels.name: Estimate: Small
labels.description: A small amount of time is probably needed to resolve this

items.title: Replace tables.yml with a dump of the postgres DDL that defines the database

labels.name: Estimate: Small
labels.description: A small amount of time is probably needed to resolve this

items.body:
It'd be great to have a generated `db/schema.sql` that shows the state of the latest version of the DB -- tables, indexes, etc.  `pg_dump` can generate this sort of thing.

The tricky bits are:
 * making this output identical on every run (regardless of minor DB version, hostname, timestamps, etc.) so that it can be checked in and not generate spurious diffs when others run it; and
 * `yarn generate` currently does not require a DB, so this means either requiring a DB to run `yarn generate`, or making this an optional generation step (perhaps `yarn generate --db-schema`?)

items.title: Worker expiration seems to be missing workers
items.body:
Details in #3032, but it seems that the expire-workers job is not expiring all workers.

The job completes in about 80s, so it's doing something but not getting overwhelmed.  It logs the number of expired workers, but that's at level INFO and we're only logging NOTICE - prod level change [here](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1645212), and let's use this issue to track changing the level of that log message in the code.

(assigned to @imbstack not necessarily to finish but to add any other findings here)
(I guess the young kids call them "learnings" now, ugh, kids these days)

items.title: aws provider should bump `worker.expires`

milestone.title: Provisioning is Efficient
milestone.description: Use whatever tools we have in our toolbox to make our provisioning spend the least money while also having good latency and throughput.

items.body:
The Azure and Google providers both update a worker's `expires` timestamp when it is set to expire in less than a day.  The AWS provider does not.

(in fact, probably this should happen in `worker-scanner.js` for all workers, so that an active worker never expires)

items.title: Port wmworker_pool_errors_entities table to use a normal DB table
items.body: This table currently uses azure-entities emulation to store its data in the DB. This bug entails writing a new DB version that will smoothly migrate the last table of the service to use a more typical DB table with nicely-named columns and easy joins.

items.title: taskcluster-db tests output to provide guidance on setting up a suitable dev environment, or how to skip db tests
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
When running `yarn test` without `TEST_DB_URL` set, the failure message says that the env var must be set to run tests, but does not describe how to skip the tests for users that don't have postgres set up, or provide more detailed setup instructions, for users that want to run the tests.

**To Reproduce**

Check out taskcluster repo, run `yarn install && yarn test`.

**Expected behavior**
If DB tests can't be run, the failure message should say how the DB tests can be skipped, or point to setup instructions (perhaps a pointer to a markdown doc in the repo).

**Taskcluster version**
Commit 9e7a0f559787963f3ccc0f6f245c6ac3605fcf85.

**Console output**
```
...
...

> taskcluster-db
$ mocha test/*_test.js test/**/*_test.js

AssertionError [ERR_ASSERTION]: TEST_DB_URL must be set to run db/ tests
    at Object.<anonymous> (/Users/pmoore/git/taskcluster/db/test/helper.js:10:1)
    at Module._compile (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:1138:30)
    at Object.Module._extensions..js (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:1158:10)
    at Module.load (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:986:32)
    at Function.Module._load (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:879:14)
    at Module.require (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:1026:19)
    at require (internal/modules/cjs/helpers.js:72:18)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/Users/pmoore/git/taskcluster/db/test/upgrade_downgrade_test.js:4:16)
    at Module._compile (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:1138:30)
    at Object.Module._extensions..js (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:1158:10)
    at Module.load (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:986:32)
    at Function.Module._load (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:879:14)
```

items.title: Deprecate old entities methods
items.body: Let's deprecate the old wmworkers, cache_purges, and wmworker_pools entities methods once #2993 lands.

items.title: [Feature request] [tc-github] Allow annotations to be configured
items.body:
Currently, Taskcluster supports [adding custom output text](https://firefox-ci-tc.services.mozilla.com/docs/reference/integrations/github/checks#custom-output-in-checks) when using Github Checks. This lets the [`output.text`](https://github.com/taskcluster/taskcluster/blob/f755e70b8674fa5a70698700b13fb654d633e000/services/github/src/handlers.js#L563) field be configured.

It would be great if the [`output.annotations`](https://developer.github.com/v3/checks/runs/#annotations-object-1) array could also be configured. This would allow tasks to add annotations to specific lines in PRs and make task output easier to read.

See [Checks](https://help.github.com/en/github/collaborating-with-issues-and-pull-requests/about-status-checks#checks) for some screenshots of how annotations appear in the Github UI.

items.title: Add support for reregister endpoint in worker-runner

labels.name: Estimate: Medium
labels.description: A medium amount of time is probably needed to resolve this

items.body:
The implementer of this issue should work closely with the implementer of  #3011.

This will make worker-runner support being handed a token back at `registerWorker` time. The token must be securely stored in a way that makes it inaccessible from tasks. It will pass this token back to worker-manager when it calls `reregisterWorker` and then update the worker with the new creds it gets in return.

This is one part of #2893

items.title: Add a reregister endoint to worker-manager

labels.name: Estimate: Medium
labels.description: A medium amount of time is probably needed to resolve this

items.body:
The implementer of this issue should work closely with the implementer of #3012 

Basic idea here is a new scope-protected endpoint in the worker-manager api that takes as input a secret token known only to worker-runner and worker-manager. It will generate and return new taskcluster creds for the worker on that instance to use. The creds will not live longer than the `reregistrationTimeout` for that worker. The endpoint will update `terminateAfter` for the worker so that worker-manager does not terminate the instance.

This will require handing out a token in the `registerWorker` endpoint and storing it in the worker row.

This is one part of #2893

items.title: generic-worker uses worker credentials instead of task credentials to download artifacts
items.body:
When mounting artifacts from other tasks, generic-worker uses the worker's creds, rather than the task's creds:
https://github.com/taskcluster/taskcluster/blob/22a6be0a3736db2442c3639e9713a2021f4d8c58/workers/generic-worker/mounts.go#L721-L731

I believe this is not a security issue as the worker credentials do not have any `queue:get-artifact:..` scopes.  This bug would only result in a worker being unable to download an artifact despite `task.scopes` having the scopes to do so.

items.title: Provide facility to run generic-worker tests against mocks

labels.name: Estimate: Large
labels.description: A large amount of time is probably needed to resolve this

items.body: In order to make it easier for contributors to locally run tests against generic-worker, implement mocks that the tests can run against.

items.title: Update worker versions report to be able to determine worker versions from existing tasks

labels.name: Estimate: Small
labels.description: A small amount of time is probably needed to resolve this

items.body:
Update the [audit worker versions](https://github.com/taskcluster/mozilla-history/tree/master/audit-worker-versions) reporting tool to be able to optionally scrape existing recent tasks to determine worker versions, rather than needing to always create new tasks.

This report is used to update

* [Firefox worker versions report](https://github.com/taskcluster/mozilla-history/blob/master/WorkerVersions/README.md)
* [Community worker versions report](https://github.com/taskcluster/community-history/blob/master/WorkerVersions/README.md)

items.title: private artifact links in ui now go nowhere
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
The link for private artifacts appears to go right back to the ui home.

**To Reproduce**

1. Go to https://community-tc.services.mozilla.com/tasks/a3TRMvMERZuRwCGHb9dpcA/runs/0#artifacts
2. Click on any of the private artifacts

**Expected behavior**
I _think_ I should be linked to the artifact? If my understanding is wrong please feel free to close. The [runs in the api](https://community-tc.services.mozilla.com/api/queue/v1/task/a3TRMvMERZuRwCGHb9dpcA/runs/0/artifacts) appear correct to me.

**Taskcluster version**
30.0.2

**Platform (please complete the following information):**

 - OS: Linux
 - Browser if applicable: Firefox
 - Version if applicable: 79.0a1 (2020-06-05) (64-bit)

items.title: Only update worker state when it changes
items.body: The `checkWorker`function for most providers currently updates the worker state on every iteration.  We can cut down DB traffic a bit by only doing so when the state actually changes.

items.title: [docker-worker] Support new container image formats
items.body:
Currently, docker-worker only supports loading images from tasks or artifacts in the [v1 image format](https://github.com/moby/moby/blob/master/image/spec/v1.md). While this is the format generated by our docker-in-docker tasks, it is no longer well supported by tools, and is hard to generate with current tools. In particular, I've need to workaround this limitation in [Bug 1626058](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1626058), by using a second tool to convert to a v1 supporting image.

This limitation is based on the code [here](https://github.com/taskcluster/taskcluster/blob/9ff7e551a64758910d60edc375490d8b5f5f13ef/workers/docker-worker/src/lib/docker/artifact_image.js#L246) that mutates the image before loading it with docker, to ensure the image name that is loaded is controlled by docker-worker.

items.title: allow using the same name for postgres functions that have changed signature
items.body: Currently to update the signature of a function, you have to change the name of the function so that the old and new one can both be stored in the db for migration purposes. This is good but a bit of a leaky abstraction. We should instead have a `version` field of functions that needs to be incremented when signatures change. We can enforce with a test that this happens. Then, in js code, we always can use the latest version of the function.

items.title: docker-worker will terminate if its idle timeout is shorter than the time it takes to call claimWork

labels.name: Estimate: Small
labels.description: A small amount of time is probably needed to resolve this

items.body:
[Setting the `afterIdleSeconds` value to 1](https://github.com/mozilla/community-tc-config/commit/2e8f6fa3a711b66ea610e06f889aa1a1ba8428fe#diff-4083ba8a0fdfa215bc0f2edbab4b7b3dR424) seems to result in workers terminating during the call to `claimWork`.

Generic-worker does not have this issue.

items.title: Support encrypted columns in postgres

labels.name: Estimate: Medium
labels.description: A medium amount of time is probably needed to resolve this

items.body:
This is required to support a token for reregistration. @djmitche and @helfi92  can help fill out the other bits of this about what we actually need to do.

Blocks #2893
